(a) Consider the system that includes only the two spheres, with Earth external to the system.

i. Write an expression for the work done moving the spheres horizontally from far apart to a separation of <math alttext="r sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (b) Now consider the system that contains both Earth and the two spheres. What is the work done on this new system for the changes in sphere position described in parts (a)(i) and (ii) ? Explain your reasoning.

(c) The rods are now held fixed at the positions shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and negative charge is added to the right sphere so its net charge is <math alttext="negative Q sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Draw a single vector originating on point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that represents the net electric field at that point.

For each of the dots on the horizontal daashed line, draw an isoline of electric potential that goes through the dot.

(d) In a new situation, the two spheres still have the same mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, but the left sphere is made of plastic and has charge <math alttext="positive Q sub P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>p</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the right sphere is made of metal and is uncharged. In terms of charge distributions, explain why the force between the spheres is attractive.
